etymologies: Middle English (in the sense ‘man of noble birth’): from gentle+ man, translating Old French gentilz hom. In later use the term denoted a man of a good family (especially one entitled to a coat of arms) but not of the nobility

definitions: a chivalrous, courteous, or honorable man

examples.text: he behaved like a perfect gentleman

definitions: a man of good social position, especially one of wealth and leisure.
(in the UK) a man of noble birth attached to a royal household
shortDefinitions: man of noble birth attached to royal household

definitions: a polite or formal way of referring to a man

examples.text: opposite her an old gentleman sat reading

shortDefinitions: polite or formal way of referring to man

definitions: used as a polite form of address to a group of men
shortDefinitions: used as polite form of address to group of men

definitions: used as a courteous designation for a male fellow member of the US House of Representatives.
shortDefinitions: courteous designation for male fellow member of House of Commons etc.
